bibl.title: Letter from Philip Showalter Hench to Jose R. Andreu, May 16, 1947

div1.p: Hench describes in detail the background of his efforts to memorialize the Camp Lazear site, and his plans for the preservation of the site and establishment of a museum. He asks Andreu about the availability of funds from the Cuban government or private sources for building and upkeep, and about costs for these efforts. Without this information and commitment from the Cubans he will find it difficult to raise funds from American sources.

div1.head: Letter from Philip Showalter Hench to Jose R. Andreu, May 16, 1947
div1.opener:
May 16, 1947
Dr. Jose R. Andreu
Minister of Public Health and Social Assistance
Republic of Cuba
Havana, Cuba
My dear Doctor Andreu:
div1.p:
Your letter of April 24th has pleased me greatly. I regret my delay
in answering it but I have been attending medical meetings in Oregon, Colorado,
Chicago and Arkansas. I have also received a letter from Doctor Pedro Negueira.

I am delighted to learn that the Cuban Government has named as a
National monument the Caseta on the Finca San Jose in Quemados where Major Walter
Reed and his associates, Doctors James Carroll and Aristides Agramonte completed
the work which proved beyond all doubt the correctness of the splendid theory of
Doctor Carlos Finlay. That part of the Finca San Jose used by the American
commission was named by Major Reed Camp Lazear in honor of their dead colleague,
Doctor Jesse W. Lazear whose preliminary successes led the way to the final
victory. The Caseta which remains was “Building Number One” described so care-
fully in official documents by Major Reed.

From the medico-historical standpoint it is a most happy coincidence
that in earlier years Doctor Finlay had performed a few of his experiments at the
very same Finca San Jose, presumably when the Jesuits occupied the main building
as a summer retreat. Thus the Finca San Jose fortunately unites the memories of
Doctor Finlay and of Major Reed and his colleagues and thus makes it eminently fitting
as the site of a Cuban-American medical memorial.

I believe that Mr. John Moran of Havana, one of Major Reed's outstanding
and earliest volunteers, has told you that the historical significance of the Finca
San Jose and of Camp Lazear and indeed their actual location were lost sight of by
medical and governmental authorities until 1939 when on a visit to Mr. Moran I con-
cluded that a site marked by a temporary sign as the supposed site of Camp Lazear
was not in fact the true site of Camp Lazear but was the location of the small
yellow-fever hospital, across the La Playa railroad track from the Camp Columbia
Hospital, in which certain spontaneous (natural) and experimental cases of yellow
fever were cared for, including Major Reed's experimental cases from Camp Lazear.
Having made this conclusion Mr. Moran, Mr. Luis Pogolotti and I set out to find the
true location of Camp Lazear and located it correctly.

When we informed certain governmental and medical personages of our find-
ings we were not surprised to note their skepticism. But despite their skepticism
and preliminary disbelief, they received us graciously and kindly and finally upon
the request of Doctor Domingo Ramos, then Secretary of National Defense, I pre-
pared a statement with documentary and photographic proof identifying the true lo-
cation of Camp Lazear and the significance of the Caseta which had fortunately and
remarkably survived through the years. This formal statement of mine in the form
of a loose-leaf notebook was sent to Doctor Ramos who deposited it in the library
of the Finlay Institute and it is presumably still there.

In view of the great medico-historical significance of Camp Lazear and of
the Finca San Jose it seemed to me appropriate to preserve the Caseta and enough
of the surrounding land (which comprised Camp Lazear) for a permanent Cuban-American
medical memorial.

Most regretfully I had become painfully aware on my visits to Cuba of
the unfortunate controversy between those who believe that Finlay did not receive
enough credit from American writers and authorities and those who believe that Reed
and his colleagues have not received their due credit at the hands of Cuban writers
and authorities. I believe this is a most unhappy controversy because the magni-
ficent conquest of yellow fever, the work of several hands, is of such tremendous
importance to the world that sufficient honors can surely be given to all concerned.
Without the astute theory and pioneer work of Doctor Finlay, Major Reed and his
colleagues might, like others, have spent fruitless years. Without the work of the
American Commission, Doctor Finlay's work might have continued in neglect without
serious consideration for many more years. Together these scientists and lovers
of their fellowmen created an immortal “team.” Their work is inseparable and my
earnest hope is that through our little memorial their memories may be inseparably
honored.

It was my hope, which Mr. Moran enthusiastically shared, that a small group
of American and Cuban physicians and sanitarians might raise enough money to build
around the Caseta an enveloping building of modest size which would become “The
Cuban-American Medical Memorial.” As Finlay came before Reed in time so it seemed
to me appropriate to designate it as the Cuban-American Memorial. My original plans
were quite modest and I had hoped to raise $20,000 to $30,000 in the United States
with the belief that perhaps a similar sum could be raised in Cuba.

My preliminary conversations with Senor Macia, the present owner of the
land once occupied by Camp Lazear, led me to believe that he would either sell me
the land for an appropriate price or that he might even join me in the project by
selling it to me for a nominal price on presenting it to the sponsors of the project
provided he was certain that the Cuban Government or medical profession would actually
accept it and care for it as a national monument. In this spirit Senor Macia
graciously gave me in 1940 a signed deed to the Caseta on the provise that I was
able to complete the project at an early date. It is quite understandable that
Senor Macia has hesitated to conclude any contract with me or others until he knew
what use would be made of the land. I have not written to or heard from Senor Macia
recently but I feel certain that he will continue to cooperate graciously with those
responsible for the project.

My own earlier efforts to interest various persons in this project and
to raise preliminary sums of money in this country were greatly handicapped by
my participation in military service between 1942 and 1946. However between 1940
and 1944 I did write on occasion to certain persons in Cuba. I regret to say that
more often than not I had no reply..

In a letter to Doctor Jose A. Presno, dated December 6, 1944, I stated
that a ranking official of the Mayo Clinic had promised me that, contingent on the
gifts of others, the Mayo Clinic or Foundation would contribute up to $10,000 for
the memorial project. Having had no reply from Doctor Presno we became fearful
that the project was of no interest to Cuban medical or governmental circles. It
is therefore with great pleasure that I have received your letter and I shall be
happy indeed to begin again the campaign and to join you and others so that we may
accomplish the project in the near future.

I had originally conceived a rather small, unpretentious memorial costing
about $20,000 to $30,000. It was to be somewhat like the enclosed diagram: a white
one-storied building of Cuban design and construction comprising essentially one large
main room big enough to contain the Caseta in its center (the Caseta being left just
where it has been, but restored somewhat). This main room would have sufficient wall

space and additional floor space for display cabinets where would be exhibited the
many souvenirs of the conquest of yellow fever which I have already been able to
collect from participants in the experiments and relatives of participants. For
example the families of Major Reed and Doctor Lazear and certain military personnel
associated with them such as Generals J. R. Kean and Albert E. Truby have already
contributed much which would be appropriate for display.

I already have a mass of material--old photographs of Camp Lazear, of the
Finca San Jose, of Camp Columbia and its hospital, and of the yellow fever hospital
taken in 1900; old maps of Camp Lazear and of Camp Columbia; most of the original
fever charts of the volunteers who developed experimental yellow fever, innumerable
letters of Major Reed to his family written from Camp Columbia in 1900 describing
in intimate detail the day by day progress of the experiments; a few rare and im-
portant letters written by Doctor Lazear to his wife describing his secret experi-
ments which ended with his death; letters of Doctor Carroll to his wife, and copies
of hundreds of official documents and reports concerning the conquest of yellow fever.
I have Doctor Lazear's microscope used by him in Cuba, medals given to Major Reed,
et cetera, et cetera.

To this collection should be added material copied or loaned by the
families of Doctors Finlay, Delgado, and Agramonte as well as certain data in possession
of the Rojas family (e.g. Doctor Rojas' day book identifying the Finca San Jose as
the site of Camp Lazear). Thus we would have in fact a Cuban-American memorial.

In one corner of the main room I planned to have placed unobtrusively an
attendant's desk and small display case where visitors would find souvenir booklets,
photographs, postcards, et cetera, the possession of which would give them full in-
formation on the significance of the memorial and the purchase of which souvenirs
might add materially to the upkeep fund. On one end of the building, and adjacent
to the main hall it would be well to have modest quarters in which the attendant or
care-taker would live--a little apartment of perhaps four rooms, a parlor, a com-
bination kitchen-dining room, a bedroom, and bath. Connected with the latter, but
with entrance into the main hall, could be two small “rest rooms” for visitors.

Mr. Moran and I have examined and re-examined the Caseta itself with anxious
eyes, wondering to what extent, if any, it could be preserved and repaired. I be-
lieve Mr. Moran has been somewhat more pessimistic that I am. I have seen buildings
in worse shape than that of the Caseta which were restored without too much dis-
figuring or replacing of the original structure and it is my hopeful belief that,
having stood the ravages of 47 years, including at least two tornadoes, the wood
of the Caseta can be treated chemically to stop the action of termites and of decay
so that it may be preserved as a visible shrine.

The additions to the original Caseta (the porch and extra rooms) should
of course be removed, the adjacent trees out down. The original casement window
(with sliding panel) on the left front as one views the Caseta has been made into
a long “French window.” It should be closed up to resemble the original one remaining
on the right end of the Caseta. When enclosed properly in the enveloping building
I would surround the Caseta with a protecting rope on standards to prevent visitors
from entering or damaging it. With the front and sides of the Caseta restored to
their original appearance I would remove most of the rear wall, exposing the interior
to the view of the visitors passing around to see it from the rear. The original
wood removed from the rear wall could be used in part to fill up the enlarged front
left window. The remainder of the original wood could be used perhaps to replace
damaged irreparable wood. Whatever of the original wood cannot be salvaged or used
should be carefully saved; out up into small pieces or plaques, suitably framed
and labelled with small metal attachments this wood could provide quite a few sou-
venirs which would be highly prized by historically minded individuals and institutions.
(May I here speak for at least one of these for myself!)

I would restore the interior with the appropriate number of beds, trunks
and boxes for soiled bedding, chairs and a stove as in the original. (We have sev-
eral accurate descriptions of the interior as it was in 1900.)

The approach to Camp Lazear should be improved by paving or otherwise im-
proving the chief road now leading thereto which is, I believe, Calle Jose Miguel
Gomez. Later another entrance should be made extending from Calle L. Valdes Carrera.
The Camp site should be cleaned up, planted with sed and perhaps flowers. On the
former site of “Building Number Two” (which was destroyed in the cyclone of 1926 but
the exact location of which we know) should be erected a small stone or marble marker
with a bronze plaque.

On the main wall surrounding the Finca San Jose somewhere between the
present iron-grilled entrance gate and the corner of Calzada Real and Calle Jose
Miguel Gomez should be placed a fairly large bronze tablet indicating the historic
significance of the Finca San Jose and the adjacent Camp Lazear. This tablet, placed
on the main street of Quemados, would attract and direct visitors to the Camp site
behind the present Finca. As you now know the site across the La Playa railroad
track adjacent to Camp Columbia (the site between this railroad track and what is
now known as Calle San Carlos O Rene Berndes) which was formerly erroneously marked
as the site of Camp Lazear was the site of four little yellow fever hospital shacks
to which the victims of experimental yellow fever were taken from Camp Lazear to
be cared for as soon as they developed their yellow fever. These little shacks had
previously housed certain military personnel ill of natural yellow fever, such as
General (then Major) J. R. Kean and others. It was in one of these little buildings
that the martyr Lazear died. Therefore would it not be most fitting for the Cuban-
American sponsors of this project to erect on this site an additional marker of
modest size (stone or marble) with a bronze plaque indicating what happened there.
This property already belongs to the Cuban government.

Doctor Andreu, in making further plans for these memorials may I ask you
frankly the following questions?
1. Will the Cuban Government be inclined to appropriate any funds to add
to those I hope to raise here?
2. If the Cuban Government cannot do this, do you believe the Cuban
medical profession would help raise funds to add to American contributions? Perhaps
the Medical College of the City of Havana or the Colegio Medico Nacional would aid
us in sponsoring the project.
3. Has Senor Macia signified his willingness to provide the camp site
either at a suitable price or for a nominal fee as a contribution to the project?
4. Once the funds have been raised to erect the memorial building who
will care for its upkeep and repairs? As a national monument will it be cared for
by the Cuban Government or will it be necessary to raise private funds for its
endowment or would the Cuban medical profession guarantee its care, especially if
they do not have to contribute to the original funds?
5. What would be the approximate original cost at current Cuban prices
of a little memorial building of the size and type I have outlined?
6. Does the Cuban Government have plans more ambitious than mine? Do
they prefer a larger, more elaborate memorial, with the museum as merely a small
part thereof, but the rest of a larger building to be used for other civic or social
purposes?
7. Assuming we build only a small memorial as I have outlined, what would
its upkeep cost in Havana: salary of attendant, repairs, gardening, et cetera?
Would the upkeep cost over $4,000 annually? If the upkeep were not guaranteed by
the government or by medical agencies it would be necessary now to raise a much
larger sum than I had anticipated in order to create an endowment yielding $4,000-
$5,000 a year. This is an important matter because there would be no sense for us
to raise funds, erect a building and then allow it and its surroundings to run down
for lack of care.

If no agency is willing to assure the upkeep of a memorial building I be-
lieve its erection would not be practicable. In this event the most that could be
done now would be the beautification of the camp site, the improvement of the road
leading thereto and the erection of four modest memorials consisting of stone or
marble pediments with bronze tablets to be placed as follows: (1) on the wall of
the Finca San Jose near the corner of Calzada Real and Calle Jose Miguel Gomez;
(2) on the site of Building Number One (the remaining Caseta); (3) on the site of
Building Number Two, and (4) on the site of the false “Campamento Lazear” where
Doctor Lazear died. These four memorials would of course not cost very much, only
a few thousand dollars, and would need a minimum of care. Certainly we must at least
do this much!

Without having some of this information at hand I cannot at this time
guarantee that the Mayo Clinic or Foundation will renew their offer to contribute
$10,000. Their offer, made in 1944, was, as I have said, contingent on the contribu-
tions of others and especially on the interest and willingness of Cuban medical and
governmental authorities to approve and join in the project or at least to accept it
and protect it once it was donated. However, I feel fairly certain that the Mayo
Clinic still looks with considerable favor on the project as they have a great ad-
miration for Doctor Finlay and for Major Reed and his colleagues, as well as a great
admiration for the Cuban people and medical profession. The governors of the Mayo
Clinic have always been most sympathetic with my own historical investigations on
the conquest of yellow fever. The physicians of the Mayo Clinic have welcomed many
distinguished Cuban physicians and patients here.

I had hoped to come to Havana this spring for my vacation but found it
impossible. Now that the Cuban Government has made the Caseta a national monument
I am especially anxious to visit Havana to discuss with you and others the plans
outlined. Perhaps a joint Cuban-American Memorial Committee should be formed to
assure the early success of the project. Certainly immediate steps must be taken
to protect the remains of the Caseta from wind and weather if we hope to preserve
it. Even if the building cannot be erected for a year or so the Caseta should be
temporarily covered with a strong wooden or galvanized iron or/ other suitable pro-
tection (roof and walls). I am sure that funds for such an immediate purpose would
be available promptly.

As soon as I hear from you or your associates I will renew at once my
efforts to raise an appropriate sum. Throughout all my investigations and dealings
Mr. John Moran has been my invaluable advisor and helper. On many occasions he has
kindly acted as my agent. He has shared my hopes and is fully aware of my plans and
intentions. May I ask you to consult him as you may wish to know of my plans and
motives. I can assure you I have no selfish or ulterior motive. I have just one
idea--to honor all the conquerors of yellow fever, in particular Doctors Finlay and
Delgado and Major Reed, his colleagues of the American Commission and their brave
volunteers. In so doing I believe the Cuban and American medical professions can
be joined in greater harmony to the end that an unfortunate and unhappy controversy
can be forgotten. To this end I shall be delighted to give more time and effort.
Believe me,
